awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  The role of oxygen fugacity in calc-alkaline differentiation and the creation of continental crust at the Aleutian arc
awd_abstract_narration: This proposal seeks to examine the role of oxygen variations in the origin of the calc-alkaline magmas that erupt at subduction-related volcanoes (arc volcanoes).  In particular, the PIs seek to determine how oxygen varies during differentiation and degassing, and see how it varies along strike of the Aleutian arc as a function of material derived from the subducted slab. The work will also include an experimental study of the relationship and interplay between H2O and fO2 during magma formation, a critical question with implications for the formation of continental crust. The PIs note that the Aleutian arc features local and regional variations in numerous geochemical features, but lacks the complexities introduced when magmas move through continental crust. The proposed work includes novel (micro XANES analysis of the ferrous/ferric ratio in glasses (a proxy for oxygen content), especially glass inclusions in mineral. Water, CO2 and major and trace elements (including Cl and S) will also be analyzed. The PIs also propose an experimental program in which fO2 is varied at constant water content. The experimental glasses will be analyzed using the same techniques as described for the natural glasses. Broader impacts include a new interactive exhibit at the Smithsonian that will include an on-line component. Material from the exhibits will be incorporated into undergraduate curricula. There will be undergraduate mentoring through REU and/or senior thesis, as well as mentoring of grad students and a post-doc.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Planet Earth is geologically unique in the solar system in that it has two types of rocky crust. The continental crust, upon which we live, is a unique composition not found on other nearby planets. Our goal in this project was to test for the effects of two major compositional factors on the crystallization of magmas that may ultimately form into continental crust. We tested the magmatic water content, which a major volcanic gas and can influence the composition and appearance of certain crystals as magma cools and crystallizes, and we also tested the oxidation state of iron, which has different chemical properties depending on whether it is in a 2+ or 3+ charged state. Our work looked at these variables in both natural volcanoes from the western Aleutian islands, and in experiments conducted under controlled conditions in the laboratory. We found that both water and iron oxidation have resolvable effects on magma crystallization and composition as it cools, but could not match the composition of continental crust by changing either variable. This means that Earth’s continents are more likely a result of different processes, other than simple crystallization.
Our work also established the water contents of several previously unstudied Aleutian volcanoes, with important consequences for hazard assessment and mitigation. These volcanoes have higher than average water contents, and abundant deposits from explosive eruptions, which means that they tend to erupt explosively. While these islands are not inhabited, explosive eruptions in this region may potentially impact regional and global air traffic.
Samples and media collected during the field work on this project, which was conducted in a fairly inaccessible area, are available open-access through the URI Marine Geological Samples Laboratory, the Alaska Volcano Observatory, and the Smithsonian Institution. These materials have been developed as teaching resources for undergraduate and graduate classes at URI.


Last Modified: 12/19/2023
Modified by: Katherine A Kelley
